summary:
The students of 1-A celebrate Christmas, and reminisce on the chaos that is Izuku Midoriya.
That's it.
notes:
Merry Christmas to all! I had a lot of fun writing this, and am proud to say it is now the longest work in the series!
And as much as I wrote this story to be a gift to you...it contains more gifts inside! Hints of what is to come are sprinkled within this story, as a promise from me to you of what will come with the coming year. See if you can spot them all! ;D

Note: This isn't the next work in the timeline. It takes place during the break between second and third term of their first year! (Aka there's at *least* a month's difference from where we are normally, giving time for many of the changes you will notice!)

With that said, please enjoy the fic! <3

(See the end of the work for more notes.)

And there we have it! This is the final installment of 2020, but don't be alarmed! More will be coming in 2021, though I don't know quite how frequently. I'll be taking on classes that require more of my time next semester for my college courses, and my AP classes are always rather time-consuming...but as I only plan to work on my priority fics (this series and Skvader), I should be fairly consistent!

So one last time for the year, let me ask...what did you think? Any thoughts, comments, questions? If you have a suggestion for a future piece, leave it in the comments! I take what you guys say to heart, truly, and I love to know what you all have to say!

Have a merry, blessed day, and until next time, au revoir! <3
text:
The students of 1-A are at ease and filled with mirth, hearts warm and content, and so too are the dorms that they reside in. Energy fills the air, a crackling not unlike the electricity that Denki Kaminari or Izuku Midoriya emit, and sound follows wherever the feeling goes. Teachers, too, roam the halls, boxes in their arms or cups grasped in their hands, much like the students that bustle around. 

Because the holidays are approaching, and although the students of 1-A do not celebrate the religion of the festivities, they still enjoy partaking in the fun that comes with the holiday known best as Christmas.

And the first step? Well, that would have to be decorations.

There are plenty to put up, too. Store bought supplies fill the boxes that teachers and students alike carry in their arms, but handmade decorations are already strewn over couches, and pieces made by arm or by leg via Creation Quirk do the same, glass baubles or replacement lights resting carefully on tabletops. A tree waits in a corner, branches ready to be fluffed and decorated.

All in all, there is much to be done, but let it not be said that 1-A is not up to the task. 

No, the twenty students are more than ready to get to work. They split into groups easily, deciding on tasks. Yaoyorozu leads the charge on decorating the walls, Sero by her side, elbows at the ready, with Asui, Jirou, and Kouda ready for instruction. Iida and Tokoyami focus on cleaning; Iida because he knew that no one else would want to, Tokoyami because Dark Shadow was a bit too excited by the shine of the ornaments for the bird-headed boy’s taste. Shouji, Ojirou, and Satou are carrying in the rest of the boxes, and making sure that nothing is in the way. Hagakure, Kaminari, Uraraka, Aoyama, and Ashido are all in charge of decorating the tree, although currently they seem to be caught in a debate on whether or not the star can be replaced by a picture of Aoyama’s face. Kirishima and Bakugou are in the kitchen, taking stock of what they have in the pantry, and trying to find out what else that they need. 

And the final three? Well…

Shinsou and Todoroki are tasked with trying to find Midoriya, because the boy disappeared not ten minutes ago.

“Have you checked underneath the tree?” Jirou asks, when Shinsou comes back into the common room with a distressed look on his face.

“He’s not under the tree,” Aizawa comments immediately, an eyebrow raised as he drinks from his coffee mug. Yagi snorts from his seat, accidentally jostling his own cup of tea. Yamada, for his part, offers a cheeky grin and adds, “Aizawa checked.”

Aizawa rolls his eyes, a huff of air escaping him. “Please. As if anyone would actually check in the tree.”

“Just did!” Kaminari chirps, unearthing himself from where he had been buried within the branches of the fake tree. “Midoriya is definitely not in there!”

“Did you check the top?” Todoroki asks, and Kaminari’s eyes widen.

“Shit, no! Thanks Todoroki, let me just….” and to Aizawa’s disbelief, the boy shoves his head back into the tree, body shifting as he presumably looks around. Aizawa chooses to turn a blind eye this time, instead staring blankly at Yamada, who struggles to hold in his laugh.

But just as Aizawa looks away, laughter begins to ring through the hall. Heads turn to see the exact green-haired boy that they were looking for, Midoriya, racing through the halls, Monoma right behind him, laughing as they chase after...a dog.

“Sweetpea!” Midoriya calls, but the name is broken with his giggling. “Sweetpea, come on!”

Sweetpea, as she’s named, simply jumps onto the couch, content to curl up next to Yagi and pant, tongue hanging out as her mouth opens into a smile of sorts. Yagi smiles, a hand reaching down to pat the dog’s head as Midoriya approaches, slowing his pace as he gets closer. 

“Sweetpea!” Midoriya says, perhaps trying to sound scolding but failing, his smile too wide to let his tone be anything but amused. 

“She ran off from Kan-sensei,” Monoma explains, falling into place by Midoriya’s side, a hand reaching out to pet Sweetpea. “Her collar was too loose, and she got a little excited.”

“She probably heard the noise being made in here,” Midoriya guesses, glancing around at all of the decorations, pausing as he spots Kaminari. “Ah, Kaminari? Why is your head in the tree?”

“Looking for Mido- oh! Midoriya! You’re back!” Kaminari pulls his head out once more, hair messier than before, earning a confused look from Midoriya in response.

“Yeah. Where can I help?” 

“Want to move the couch for us?” Hagakure asks. “We want to get people closer to the tree!”

“Oh, sure!” Midoriya says, and Uraraka turns, moving closer as she lifts her hands, ready to lighten the couch, and kick her teachers off of the furniture.

Only to pause, because Midoriya is already holding up the couch, lifting it high above his head and smiling obliviously.

“Where do you need it, exactly?” Midoriya asks, ignorant to the silence of the room. 

“Mido?” Ashido asks in lieu of responding, and Midoriya tilts his head. “You...you do know that Aizawa-sensei and Yamada-sensei are still on the couch, right?”

And indeed they are, the two teachers clutching their drinks just a little bit tighter as they try not to shift around, not wanting to be the reason that Midoriya drops them. But Midoriya just blinks at Ashido before nodding.

“Of course!” Then, worried, “Oh! Did you two want off the couch? I can set you down, if you’d like.”

“Did we -” Yamada begins to wheeze, voice rising, but Aizawa cuts him off.

“Don’t worry about it,” Aizawa says, voice calmer than he feels. “Just put the couch where it needs to be.”

“Got it! Where to, Hagakure?”

Hagakure gestures vaguely, but it seems to be enough for Midoriya because he happily moves the couch, setting the furniture and his teachers down without complaint. 

“You know what,” Monoma says, after the silence stretches on for forty long seconds, “I think I’m just going to...go.” Picking up Sweetpea, he mutters, “I preferred it when Midoriya was acting as me, instead of...whatever that was. Fucking overpowered protagonist-like nerd, why do I even-” 

The rest of Monoma’s remark is lost, the boy shutting the dorm’s door behind him. Another beat of silence fills the air, and then Kaminari softly murmurs, “I still think Midoriya did better as Snipe. That was his best role.”

And chaos breaks out at last.

“No way,” Uraraka disagrees. “Deku was so much better as Present Mic!”

“I think he did really well as All Might,” Ojirou pipes up as he sets down a box, offering a shrug and a smile. “I mean, we all saw his face during that!”

“And the fake blood was pretty cool!” Kirishima agrees, and then pauses. “That was fake, right?”

Midoriya smiles, but doesn’t answer. The conversation continues too quickly for Kirishima to fully notice this, with Ashido scoffing and shouting, “ Please ! It was when Midori was Aizawa! I mean, come on ! That was the best!”

“It did catch us off guard,” Iida admits, a hand coming up to hold his chin. “After all, it was the first assignment Midoriya did by himself. We had all assumed that the assignments ended with the single event, so Midoriya’s appearance was rather shocking.”

“And he expelled the grape,” Hagakure murmurs, and some of her peers nod along with satisfaction.

“I also have to agree that Aizawa was one of the best,” Shinsou says at that, now leaning against a wall. “Got me into 1-A faster.”

“But you never saw it!” Uraraka protests. “So how can you vote for Midozawa if you weren’t there !”

“Fair enough,” Shinsou murmurs, and then says, “Alright. I guess my favorite was uh...who was the yellow caped man?”

“Oh no,” Iida, Todoroki, and Yagi say at once, eyes widening in sync.

“Yeah, that guy,” Shinsou says with a grin. “I’ve never seen class rep. so terrified. It was great.”

“Shinsou!” Iida shouts. “That’s hardly a reason to approve of Midoriya’s acting!”

“His Nedzu impression made half of the teachers look ready to quit,” Jirou pipes up. “I think Mic-sensei almost cried.”

“I did,” Yamada murmurs.

“Okay, but I’m pretty sure every teacher ditched classes when Midoriya was Midn-”

“We don’t talk about that,” Aizawa cuts in, and Kaminari closes his mouth, nodding quickly.

“I liked seeing him as Bakugou,” Todoroki murmurs. “He looked good in the costume.”

“That’s because my costume is the best!” Bakugou shouts from the pantry.

“No, he’s just-”

“We aren’t talking about that, either,” Aizawa cuts in, eyes narrowed, and Todoroki wisely closes his mouth as well, but not before letting out a quiet laugh.

“What about you, Midoriya?” Asui asks. “Which assignment was the most fun for you?”

“Oh!” Midoriya perks up, eyes widening with delight. “Well, it had to be when I was-”

Ding!

“Oh! My cookies are done!” Satou exclaims. “I’m trying out a new recipe for the party, who wants to try one?”

“Me!” Hands fly into the air, and tasks are forgotten as the students of 1-A follow Satou into the kitchen, eager for treats.

Yes, the day is off to a wonderful start. And in just a few short days, the party will be worth the preparation.

-----

It’s the night before the party, and Shouto Todoroki is heading to his dorm, ready to sleep after the long day that has just passed. 

A fun day, surely, but also a tiring one. Even now, Todoroki’s hands tingle, half of him bordering on that oddly prickling numbness that only long sessions of Quirk usage can bring him. But Todoroki can’t complain, not when using his cold side to try creating snow for Midoriya earned the dual-toned boy that bright-eyed joy that Midoriya gives him so freely and openly.

So maybe Todoroki is tired, but it’s nothing compared to the rush of energy that he felt when Midoriya beamed at him, eyes shut from the force of his happiness.

Distracted by thoughts of the green-haired boy, Todoroki doesn’t notice the person following him until they grab him by the arm, yanking him into a room.

Turning around, Todoroki is surprised to find himself face to face with a determined-looking Uraraka.

“Uraraka?” Todoroki asks, and is given a mischief-filled smile in return. 

“Todoroki!” Uraraka cheers, as if she is surprised to see him despite being the one to pull him aside. “How are you?”

“I’m...well. Did you need something?”

“No! But I know what you need!” And then, with a flourish, Uraraka pulls out a plant with red berries and green leaves.

“Food?”

“No!” Uraraka shakes the plant in front of his face, then shakes her head. “It’s mistletoe, Todoroki! You kiss people when you stand under it with them.”

“Oh.” Todoroki glances up at the mistletoe, and then at her. “Sorry, I don’t really want to kiss you.”

“No!”

“No?”

“Oh kami….Todoroki, I don’t want to kiss you,” Uraraka says.

“Oh. Thank you.”

“ Thank y - Todoroki, you want to kiss Midoriya, right?”

Todoroki doesn’t think that he can be blamed for how half of his body immediately lights up, fire brightening up the room and forcing Uraraka to jump back. Luckily, he manages to extinguish himself just as quickly, now covered in ice.

“Yes,” Todoroki says, calmly.

Uraraka stares at the frosted boy, then sighs. Regaining her game face, she nods and says, “Alright! So, if you want to get that kiss-”

“Without Aizawa-sensei killing me,” Todoroki interrupts, and Uraraka nods along.

“ Without Aizawa-sensei killing you,” Uraraka adds in. “Then here’s what you need to do.”

In Todoroki’s defense, he only sets himself on fire four more times during the discussion.

And as Todoroki falls asleep, he hopes that tomorrow will go as planned.

-----

The day of the party begins early, but only for two people. Katsuki Bakugou and Izuku Midoriya move around the kitchen, caught in their own rhythm as they prepare for the day.

“Learn how to cook,” Bakugou mutters to himself, voice filled with loathing as he pulls out the recipe books that are well-used and worn down, carried by him since his childhood. “It’ll be calming, they said. You’ll be relaxed, they said!”

“No one said that,” Midoriya murmurs, quieter than Bakugou for once as he makes his way from the pantry to the stove, setting things down on the counter. “And besides, we don’t have to start cooking until later. If we had pulled out everything earlier-”

“As if we could ,” Bakugou cuts in. “Please, Sugar High was too busy baking his fucking goods, he would’ve just gotten a mess on our stuff.”

Midoriya snorts. “Alright, Kacchan. But still. It’ll be nice.”

“Whatever. Just make sure to be down here in time, I’m not doing all of the work without you.”

“Wouldn’t dream of missing it, Kacchan,” Midoriya responds, and then the two fall back into silence.

By the time that anyone comes down, the boys will be gone, no one around to see the moment of perfect cohabitation that the two had created. 

Later, however, all will see the peace between the two, the ease with which each boy moves around the others.

And it will be clear that maybe, just maybe, the boys are on their way to a beautiful friendship. Their past may always linger, but their future can be brighter, better. 

Miracles do come true; they just need a bit of work put into them first.

And Bakugou has put in plenty of work, which Midoriya sees clearly.

Yes, the day will be wonderful, and it starts off this way as well.

-----

Todoroki watches as Midoriya moves around the common room, shifting couches and tables this way and that. Iida had asked him to do so, Todoroki recalls, because Aizawa had warned them that a few extra people would be coming over.

Who, exactly, Todoroki is unsure of. He wonders if any of them are Aizawa’s friends...does the man have more friends?

Todoroki thinks it’s wise not to ask. Or, at least, not to ask his teacher. Midoriya, however, probably knows. He knows a lot, especially now that he’s done so much research for his acting assignments. 

...Yeah, Todoroki is curious enough to inquire. So as Midoriya dances around the common room, flitting between pieces of furniture, Todoroki walks into the room and over to the green-haired boy.

“Midoriya,” Todoroki greets, and Midoriya startles, whipping around before beaming brightly at him.

“Todoroki!” Midoriya cheers, task forgotten in his excitement. “Do you need help with anything?”

“Does Aizawa-sensei have any friends?” Todoroki asks in response, and Midoriya pauses.

“I- what?”

“Does he have any friends?” Todoroki asks. “Other than Mic-sensei, that is. Or any of the staff, actually.”

Midoriya blinks at him oddly, tilting his head slightly as he gathers his thoughts. “Of course he does,” Midoriya answers, confident and sure of his words, and Todoroki believes him. “The detective seems to be a friend, for one. I’m sure that Aizawa considers multiple of his coworkers friends as well, even if they are not as close as Yamada-sensei and Kayama-sensei are with him. Why?”

“I was just curious,” Todoroki admits easily, and Midoriya laughs.

“Alright, Todoroki! Are you ready for tonight?” 

“Yeah,” Todoroki says with a nod, and Midoriya smiles even wider.

“Great! I’m really excited! I think Aizawa said that Eri is coming over, and it’s going to be her first Christmas! And I know Yagi is bringing over a few people so...oh. Oh no.”

“What’s the matter?” Todoroki asks, and Midoriya lets out a sigh.

“All of Yagi’s friends are tall .” Midoriya looks around, glancing at the set up. “I accounted for leg room for students, and even for Aizawa and Yamada, but…” Another sigh, and then Midoriya nods to himself, determination taking over. “Right! I’ll just…”

Midoriya walks away, starting to readjust some of the seats to properly distance them from the tables, and Todoroki watches with silent admiration for another moment before turning to leave the room, so that he is no longer in the way.

Only to spot a mix of red and green on the ceiling, right above where he and Midoriya were standing.

Oh come on . 

-----

The party begins not with a bang, nor a rush, but rather a slow trickle of students entering the common room, one by one or two by two, dressed in festive hats and matching coats, bundled in red, white, green, and even blue. Friends compliment each other on their outfits, talk about the winters of the past, and find spots to sit in. Some roam the room, still giddy over the lights on the wall, the decorations on the tree, the warmth of joy in the air. Still others go so far as the kitchen, where Midoriya, Bakugou, and Satou claim their own spots, Satou furthest across the area. They offer their assistance, and are denied as patiently as the speaker can be. The work for the day is nearly done, and now is the time to relish in this truth. 

The first teacher to come is Yamada, unsurprisingly, the man eager as he walks in, carrying a box with treats inside.

“Good evening, listeners!” Yamada cries. “I brought some food!”

“Oh, thank you!” Yaoyorozu says, always one to be polite. “I can bring those to the kitchen if you’d like.”

“I’ve got it, but thanks! You just enjoy yourself, alright?” Getting a nod from the vice representative, Yamada happily enters the kitchen area, earning a smile from Midoriya and Satou, and a side glance from Bakugou before the boy goes back to his work.

“Need any help?” Yamada asks as he places his container down, careful to keep it out of the way, and receives three headshakes in response.

“No thank you, Yamada-sensei,” Midoriya says, half-distracted by what he’s doing. “Satou will probably be done in the next fifteen minutes, and Kacchan and I won’t be much longer! You can go ahead and find a spot to sit, if you’d like!”

“Alright, sprout,” Yamada responds, then listens to the boy’s directions, taking a seat and letting the other students- namely Kaminari and Sero- pull him into a conversation about English memes.

Up next comes Aizawa with Eri, who pulls away from Aizawa the moment she spots Midoriya. She does not get kicked out of the kitchen, unsurprisingly, but rather follows Midoriya around like a duckling would its mother, eyes sparkling with an intense curiosity as she watches him move. The students of 1-A coo at this, some less subtly than others.

The last three to trickle in are Yagi and his two guests. Tsukauchi and Sasaki follow the blond man inside, earning a round of greetings as they take off their shoes and coats. Yagi and Sasaki move over to the couches, where students greet them, some with warmth and others with interest as to who the green and yellow haired man may be, while Tsukauchi moves closer to the kitchen.

As if on cue, Midoriya’s head lifts just as Tsukauchi reaches his area, and the boy smiles as he says, “Oh! Detective Tsukauchi, how have you been?” 

Tsukauchi smiles at the kid, offering a shrug as he says, “Same as usual.”

“Like Aizawa-sensei?” Midoriya asks, which is merely the polite way to say ‘tired and drinking far too much caffeine’, and Tsukauchi lets out a laugh.

“Exactly like him. How have you been, sport?”

(Suddenly, Tsukauchi feels eyes glaring down on him, gazes intense at the mention of such a familial nickname. It’s worth it, though.)

(Definitely worth it, even if he can feel his Quirk being erased. Tsukauchi will never grow tired of messing with the dads of this green-haired prodigy.)

“I’ve been well!” Midoriya says, as if no one is trying to kill Tsukauchi with their glare alone.

“Those assignments haven’t been too time-consuming, huh?” Tsukauchi asks, and Midoriya shakes his head.

“Nope! Has work?”

“It always is,” Tsukauchi jokes, and Midoriya laughs. 

The glaring stops, and Tsukauchi huffs out a laugh of his own. Yeah, Tsukauchi is happy to spend his evening here, where he can see his blond twig of a friend and his honorary nephew all at once.

“Food is done, nerd,” Bakugou says, and Midoriya perks up.

“Perfect! Everyone, come eat!” Midoriya says, and no one even considers disobeying the teenager’s orders, happy enough to listen.

And so the party goes on, happy and lively and just right.

-----

Dinner finishes slowly but surely, with empty plates and matching cups, and smiles to be shared all around. A few of the students, those who felt they did less preparations than others, or perhaps just felt like helping, gather the dishes, washing them while the rest of the group slowly moves back to the common room. 

And oh, isn’t it a sight to see. Presents are poured out around the Christmas tree, and the students of 1-A take delight in how Eri stares in wide-eyed wonder at the pile. 

“What’s going on?” Eri asks, and Midoriya smiles down at her, sitting next to the girl on the couch. 

“It’s a gift exchange,” Midoriya explains. “People bring gifts, and then we all receive one.”

“Some people call it a ‘secret santa’ event, kero,” Asui adds on. “Everyone got assigned someone else.”

“But I didn’t get anyone?” Eri points out, but Aizawa cuts in before Midoriya can try to comfort the girl.

“You did, Eri,” Aizawa promises. “We went shopping for them just last week.”

“But…” Then, suddenly, Eri lights up, eyes widening as she asks, “I get to give him the secret santa?” 

“You did!” Yamada confirms. “But he still has to wait a few more moments before he can know, alright? It’s part of the fun!”

Eri looks at Midoriya at that statement, eyes shining with confusion, but she nods along when Midoriya gives a nod of his own.

“Alright!” Determined, Eri nods once more. “I’ll give it to him first, though!”

“That we can do!” Yamada assures, and Midoriya smiles at the joy in the girl’s expression as she bounces over to the pile of presents, clearly searching for the one she remembers picking out.

“She’s grown,” Midoriya murmurs, watching as Eri tugs a bag out of the pile, hoisting it up. “She’s happier.”

“She’s gained a muttering habit,” Aizawa comments idly. “When she’s really happy, she talks as fast as you.”

“Taking after her older brother, huh?” Shinsou asks, dropping onto the floor in front of Midoriya, who stares at the boy, bewildered.

“Older...brother?”

“You,” Todoroki says, blunt as always as he steals the spot beside Midoriya, and Midoriya laughs.

“I always did want a little sibling,” Midoriya admits, to which Shinsou snorts.

“So you picked one out for yourself, huh?”

“Just like he picked out his da-” Todoroki’s comment is cut off by a scarred elbow jabbing him in the stomach, but the intention is already clear. Midoriya blushes as Aizawa stares at them, unblinking as his expression remains blank.

And then, calmly, “She called you her brother just two days ago.”

And then Aizawa gets up and walks over to Eri, leaving Midoriya to be a mess on his own. 

“Well said, from Eri’s dad,” Shinsou teases. “I guess you’re officially his kid, huh?”

“It’s been official for a long time,” Todoroki mutters, and Midoriya turns red all over again. But this time he can’t fix his flustered state in time, Eri approaching with the bag.

“Merry Christmas, Deku!” Eri cheers, shoving the bag at him. “Here’s your santa!”

“Thank you, Eri,” Midoriya says, sincere as he carefully takes the gift from her hands. 

“Open it!” Eri urges immediately, and Midoriya nods along, already taking out the gift paper on top, and pulling out the item inside.

Or, rather, the first item. Because there are three things, from what Midoriya can feel, that are inside the bag. 

The first is a camera. It’s a cute one, painted a light green, and made to print off pictures the moment he takes them. Simple but sweet, Midoriya assures Eri that he’ll use it as soon as he gets the chance to.

The second is a...box? Well, it’s a rather nice looking case, Midoriya will give it that. 

“Open it,” Aizawa says, and Midoriya nods, unlatching the box and opening the top. 

Oh. It’s filled with products. Makeup, brushes, and even some small things of hair dye. And while some of the products seem cheaper, Midoriya can tell that others are very good quality- he’s seen some of these being carried by Yaoyorozu once or twice, and he knows that she’d only want the best for her money’s worth, after all. The box- er, makeup case- alone is probably worth more than his teacher should have spent, so-

“It’s a gift from all of your teachers, too,” Aizawa explains, and Midoriya blinks up at him in surprise. “The camera was from Eri, she said that she saw pictures on your wall, and wanted to give you something for that. The products are from Mic, Midnight, and….Snipe, actually. Cementoss and Power Loader designed the case so it could hold more weight, and Ectoplasm recommended the dyes.”

“Oh,” Midoriya whispers, ignoring the fact that, well...he doesn’t even know if Ectoplasm has hair underneath his costume. “I’ll have to thank them, then.”

“The last one is from Nedzu, All Might, and myself,” Aizawa says, just as Midoriya reaches in and pulls out an envelope. The green-haired boy rips it open carefully, and pulls out the paper within.

Only to pause in surprise. Because these aren’t just papers.

They’re tickets.

To HeroCon . The biggest event for hero fanatics in all of Japan, where cosplayers and die-hard fans meet and get to bond over great heroes and the community they’ve sparked, and some heroes even show up to host panels and talks and meet and greets and-

Wow.

“ Thank you ,” Midoriya whispers, and Aizawa snorts.

“If we’re giving you these assignments, we might as well give you the resources to make it better for you,” Aizawa says, but Midoriya sees the smile that he’s hiding in his capture weapon. Offering a grin to Eri, he lets Aizawa’s excuse pass, nodding along before peering at the girl who stares right back.

“Thank you, Eri,” Midoriya says softly. “I love it.”

“It was a good secret santa?” Eri asks, and Midoriya nods.

“The best,” he assures, and Eri beams before lunging at him, hugging him tightly. Midoriya hugs back immediately, blinking away the happy tears that try to form.

Tears that inevitably fall, but with laughter joining in, when Tokoyami reveals Eri to be his giftee by handing her a sword that is twice her size. The look on Aizawa’s face is enough to coax the sound right out of him, and Aizawa shoots him a heatless glare.

“I’m disowning you,” Aizawa mutters, but then he reaches out and pats Midoriya on the head, and Midoriya knows that it’s been a wonderful day, with many more to come.

-----

“Goodbye, Sir! Goodnight, Yagi!” Midoriya says, and Yagi and Sasaki both return the farewells before exiting the dorms and walking away, leaving Midoriya standing at the entrance. Midoriya smiles, watching as they go. Even now, he’s still glad that the two were able to repair their past friendship. It would have been a shame if they never got the chance, but they did and that’s what matters.

“You’re going to get cold if you stand out here,” Todoroki says, now standing besides Midoriya. “Unless you have a heat Quirk of your own?”

“I don’t,” Midoriya promises with a smile. “Though I know it’d be useful.”

“You can...stand closer to me, if you’d like,” Todoroki offers, lifting up his arm, and Midoriya grins wider before slipping into place, basking in the boy’s warmth.

“You’re like a heater,” Midoriya notes. 

“Thank you,” Todoroki responds, and then, slowly, “I think.”

“It’s good!” Midoriya assures, shifting closer. “Definitely good.”

“Okay.”

Silence fills the air, but it’s not a bad thing. It’s peaceful, calming, like a blanket of comfort draped in the space that surrounds them. Midoriya and Todoroki watch the area before them, watch how Yagi and Sasaki drift further out of sight with every passing moment, two figures going into the night.

“Today was nice,” Todoroki says, speaking up, brushing away the quiet but not quite breaking it. “I don’t know if I’ve ever had a day like today. It’s always rather quiet at home.”

“This was new for me, too,” Midoriya says in turn. “In the past, it was always my mom and I when it came time for celebrations. But today...it’s like finding a second family, isn’t it?”

“It is.” A pause, and then, slyly, “A family that gives you two fathers and multiple aunts and uncles, yeah?”

“Todoroki!” Laughing, Midoriya nudges the boy. “You’re never going to let me live that down, huh?”

“You have to be related to one of them,” Todoroki says, standing his ground. “I just can’t decide if it’s All Might or Aizawa. You’re equally like both of them, although I don’t know which is more terrifying when they’re focused on being your parent.”

“Terrifying?” Midoriya asks, and Todoroki just gives him a look.

“One day, you’ll understand,” Todoroki says vaguely, and Midoriya snorts. Silence falls once more, a pleasant lull in the conversation.

And then, suddenly, Midoriya turns, glancing upwards before smiling at Todoroki. 

“What’s that look for?” Todoroki asks, but Midoriya simply leans in, planting a kiss on the boy’s cheek before slipping out of his grasp.

“I should go check on Eri,” Midoriya says softly, and then he disappears back inside, leaving Todoroki alone, doing his best not to set the entrance on fire as he tries to understand what just happened.

And then, as Todoroki tries to calm his racing heart, he notices something above him.

Dangling from the doorway, a lone sprig of mistletoe hangs above his head.

“Oh,” Todoroki whispers, before touching his cheek. A smile creeps onto his face, soft and full of love.

It seems that Uraraka’s plan worked, after all.

Shouta watches his students as they leave the common room, one by one. The other adults are long gone, by now, either heading back home or to the teachers’ dorms, where another party awaits- one that will inevitably be more chaotic, and will last much longer into the night. Shouta doesn’t mind missing the beginning, not at all, content to watch Hizashi and Yagi head off without him. 

No, Shouta does not mind at all. Not as he sees his students whisper soft goodnights to one another, nor when he sees Asui lead Eri away, off to a sleepover with the other girls, a way to keep the young girl away from the party-induced chaos that will inevitably occur. He simply watches them go on their own merry ways, some more quickly than the rest, until at last the room is still and he sees no one else moving. 

Only then, when the air is calm and the dorms are silent, does Shouta move to leave, standing up from where he had leaned against the counter, heading into the common room.

And this is when Shouta huffs out a laugh, a smile slipping onto his face as he sees a familiar green head of hair poking over the couch. The boy is fast asleep, curled into the side of an also sleeping Todoroki. The two look calm and content, worn out from the day of excitement that has gone on.

Moving silently, Shouta grabs a blanket from the couch, one that is a blur of green, red, and white, and drapes it over the two students. Izuku shifts at the sudden weight, eyes squeezing shut before blinking open slowly.

“Aizawa?” The boy asks, head tilting, unconsciously leaning more into his classmate. 

“Just go to sleep, kiddo,” Shouta says, and Izuku nods before shutting his eyes, head dropping back down, eyes closing once more. Shouta smiles, heart warming at the ease that Izuku falls asleep, that the boy is relaxed enough to do so. Without thinking about it, Shouta can’t help but lean forward, patting the boy’s hair once, twice, before dropping his hand and backing up.

“Merry Christmas, Problem Child,” Shouta whispers, and then he leaves the room, and nothing remains except for the crackling of fire, the glow of joys recently passed, his Problem Child and the kid’s admirer.

And in the end, that’s the only way that Shouta could ask for the way to end. His students happy, his kid loved, and the day passed without incident. 

‘ Merry Christmas ,’ Shouta thinks, and the winter night sings the words right back to him.
